definitions.definition: ( transitive , obsolete ) To bend ; to fold ; to mould ; ( figuratively ) to adapt , to modify ; to change (a person's) mind , to cause (a person) to submit .
( intransitive ) To bend, to flex ; to be bent by something, to give way or yield (to a force , etc.).

main_definition: ( transitive , obsolete ) To bend ; to fold ; to mould ; ( figuratively ) to adapt , to modify ; to change (a person's) mind , to cause (a person) to submit .
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive ) To bend, to flex ; to be bent by something, to give way or yield (to a force , etc.).

examples: He plied his trade as carpenter for forty-three years.

definitions.definition: To wield or use (a tool , a weapon , etc.) steadily or vigorously .
examples: He plied his ax with bloody results.

definitions.definition: To press upon; to urge persistently .
examples: to ply someone with questions or solicitations

definitions.definition: To persist in offering something to, especially for the purpose of inducement or persuasion .

examples: The steamer plies between several ports on the coast.

definitions.definition: To manoeuvre a sailing vessel so that the direction of the wind changes from one side of the vessel to the other; to work to windward , to beat , to tack .

secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To wield or use (a tool , a weapon , etc.) steadily or vigorously .
( transitive ) To press upon; to urge persistently .
( transitive ) To persist in offering something to, especially for the purpose of inducement or persuasion .
( ambitransitive , transport ) To travel over (a route ) regularly .
( intransitive , nautical , obsolete ) To manoeuvre a sailing vessel so that the direction of the wind changes from one side of the vessel to the other; to work to windward , to beat , to tack .
